content.description: Start at the bottom of rock wall. Traverse uphill and finish back on the ground.
content.protection: None! Its a low traverse.
content.location:
A bit hidden. See beta picture and follow GPS data.

 Follow blue trail down hill from the Iron Spike area, take first left to continue on blue loop, walk aprox 100 yards and look for very faint trail uphil through some young pines (Pictures).

 The climb is up to your left from this access. Look for a jumble of rocks.

 GPS data: 43.483355,-70.451967

content.description: Just climb it
content.protection: Pad or spongy leaves and a friend. Landing zone is alright.
content.location: Second line from the left. Good clean fun.

content.description: start matched on the low on the left edge and move up with a couple hard moves.See comment by Zelenograd Wilson, broken hold may have changed grade. R Hall, NH Adam.
content.protection: 1 Pad. Be careful of the drop on your right you wouldn't want to fall off it.
content.location: On the main trail as you walk in up on the left. Easy to see sticking up in the air

content.description: Start on juggy side pull to the left and wide pinch to the right. Transition to line of drilled monos to the left, then use small crimps to a slopey top out.PG13 because of a small boulder located in the fall line when you get further to the left.Didn't get to finish due to rain, and I'm not local,  but would love to see it go.
content.location: Located on murder rocks, problem branches left.

content.description:
For the full difficulty do not use the diagonal crack on the left.

 Using drilled monos and the arete only crank this otherwise straight forward line to a challenging paddle problem.
content.protection: Pad
content.location:
West side of the Pinnacle. Up the right line of drilled monos.

 Make sure to dodge the rusted metal.

 GPS data: (43.4819320,-70.4529740)

content.description: A fun overlooked problem. Sit start the obvious holds. The crux is topping out with marginal feet. A fall from the top would be unfortunate.
content.protection: Pad and spotter
content.location: On the way to Iron Spike from the main park entrance.

content.description: Sit start the obvious holds. Stand on the flake and fire for the top.
content.protection: Pad
content.location: On your way to Iron Spike. On the right side of the blue trail.

content.description: It starts to the right; on the first step of the exit path. Immediately head for bottom right of roof.. getting under to left side of roof and up is the crux.
content.protection: Use trees to the right as anchors. Bring 50ft. Of webbing. Also Rotten granite
content.location: It’s to the right of “iron spike”. null

content.description: Creepy Flake makes it fun.
content.location: Behind iron spike anchors. If you’re at the top looking down at iron spike wall just turn around. You’ll see a drop off 10 feet away. Follow it down. It’s part of the same outcrop so you can’t see it from iron spike.  To the right of “rock slug”

content.description: Sit start with one hand on either side of the arete and work your way up and left. A bit sharp and not super proud, but had some really good movement. If someone has climbed this before just let me know!
content.protection: 1 or 2 pads
content.location: When looking at "Eaten Alive" it is the arete just to your right.

content.description:
Start up the north face arete of the Pinnacle. 

 Balance moves and some fun liebacking to the top.
content.protection: Pad
content.location:
North side arete of the Pinnacle.

 GPS data: (43.4819320,-70.4529740)

content.description:
The left most line on the boulder. Easy moves up a gracious crack. 

 Fun for first timers
content.protection:
TR off of crack on the opposite side of the boulder. .75, 1 and assorted nuts can build a bomber anchor. Long runners or rope to extend anchor. See picture.

 Bouldering goes at V0
content.location: A huge, hard to miss boulder off of the blue trail.  GPS data: (43.4840831,-70.4502941)

content.description: Just a small short boulder with a mini dyno.
content.location: Just off the black trail43.4836528, -70.4439778

content.description:
Wonderful face with about 3 variations. Each with their own personality. 

Great for laps and practicing slab techniques. Fire away.
content.protection: TR or highball. See Slabcrack beta
content.location: The face directly right of the Slabcrack (5.5) GPS data: (43.4840831,-70.4502941)

content.description: Cool start. Foot on furthest rock. Hand on low outcrop.
content.location: Down behind “iron spike” anchors. Wall starts 10 feet behind anchors for iron spike. Follow to the end.  To the left of “Spinal Flake”

content.description: Named after the bottle of Red Stripe found at the base of the problem.  Short, 3-move problem.  Start on the lower stable flake, move up and get a heel hook to top out.  I would check the integrity of the flake before committing.
content.location: Enter the mini quarry on the left on the Yellow Trail, directly after the Pinnacle boulder.  Go to the short wall to your right.  This is the leftmost problem on that wall.

content.description:
Rock quality is the crux right now. Some flakey rock will sluff off as more climb this beautiful solitary boulder. 

 Pure V-easy fun
content.protection: Pad and friend, or small pool of water
content.location:
Continue down the hill after walking South West on the Blue Trail. Follow the most prominent trail for about 100 yards. The Pinnacle is on the West side of the trail just after a small stream crossing and before the clearing on your right. 

 If the you see the clearing on your right you've gone too far. Look back into the brush just north of the clearing and you'll see it.

 GPS data: (43.4819320,-70.4529740)

content.description:
Quality sequence with a committing top out. Start in the center on a lyback, hit the jug above and move left on to crimpy sidepulls, then straight up to top out. Super fun!

Located off of the green trail deeper in the park. This hidden climb is easy to miss.  The window of climbable days is also small. There needs to be about 2-3 days of dry weather for the landing to be bearable. Water pools below climb on wet days.
content.protection: Crash Pad...or spongy leaves and a friend
content.location:
Hidden steps away from the Green Trail. The climb is on the backside of an in-cut mini quarry.

GPS data: (43.4830852,-70.4461833)

content.description:
Starts right of the crack. 

Easy slab climbing to a foot rail and then the real challenge begins.

Look for the magic bean!
content.protection: Pad or parkour
content.location:
If walking east off of the black trail there is a large cluster of boulders to your right. 

 This is the most prominent boulder with a crack up the left side.

content.description:
Start left of the crack. Undercling the left face, delicate foot traverse to lyback. Get to the top.

 **Don't use the tree**
content.protection:
Pad or spongy leaves

 **None of the falls here are clean...just don't fall**
content.location:
Large boulder with large peace-sign spraypainted on it. This climb is the left most crack in the area. A tree marks the base of the route.

 The Peace Stem area is on the south side of the Blue Trail. Look at main page Climbing Map for general location.

 GPS Data: (43.484168,-70.451607)

content.description:
The easiest variation of the Iron Spike climbs. Right up the middle and head climbers right to avoid the roof section.

 Nothing especially wild about this climb but when there is nothing to climb within 1.5hrs of this town...this route is king.

 Go get some laps!
content.protection: TR. Sling the spike with a double length and slot some nuts for a decent 2 point anchor. A quad is a nice self equalizing master point for this climb.
content.location: The Main Quarry access is closest to the Community Bike Center (CBC) - communitybike.net/Be courteous of this access point and get involved with their mission if you feel inspired. Park just after the CBC on Sheltra Ave and then walk through the CBC parking lot. Head past the gate towards the park. Head right, bearing 45deg, to the uphill path. At the top of the hill, the trail splits left and should lead to a prominent spray-painted boulder. Past the boulder is an obvious boulder field that crosses the Main Quarry. Scramble across this boulder field and top out. Go right and walk the cliffs to the end. Look for a large iron spike with a piton wedged at its base.GPS data: (43.4834452,-70.4539372)

content.description:
Same start as Iron Spike (5.7). This variation moves left and directly through the roof section. 

 Some convienetly placed quarry holes make for much needed finger holds. 

 Its one move wonder 5.10 to a sweet mantle. If you don't know the beta its a nice boulderly move. Ya make do with whatcha got...ya know?

 Enjoy!
content.protection: Same TR as Iron Spike (5.7)
content.location: Same TR as Iron Spike (5.7)

content.description:
Variation of Iron Spike (5.7). Climber's left arete to the top.

 Similar to Iron Roof...its a one move wonder 5.9 to get through the roof.
content.protection: TR and a #2 is nice to redirect just below the anchor.
content.location: Same as Iron Spike (5.7)

content.description: Beginning slab shiz with side crimp probably the crux. I don’t know. It’s the first move. Go straight up to pines.
content.protection: Same trees to the right for anchors as “squasher” bring 50feet of webbing.
content.location: In between “iron spike” and “squasher”.  Start on slab to the left of the plants hanging out on the tiny ledge at the bottom.

content.description: Ascend the right trending seam. Sit start to the right of the pine tree. Right hand on the obvious hold. left hand low in the seam. Good luck finding the feet that work for you. Short, powerful. awkward. fun.
content.protection: pad if you wish
content.location: On the small set of boulders behind the Iron bolt. This is on the face that is facing the trail.

content.description: A short but awesome climb! Starts with a left hand on the low crimpy rail, a right on the nice jutting edge, a left in the low crack, and a right heel up on the right ledge. Quick left hand move to the next crimp above then match. Bring the left foot up a little to a solid spot and shoot for the  top with whatever hand feels comfortable. Pull up with good feet and top out.
content.protection: A pad
content.location: Immediately to the right of Stand and Deliver

content.description:
The crux is getting out of the cave. 

 Sit start for the full tick....try not to be Eaten Alive!
content.protection: Pad or nothing
content.location:
The farthest boulder in the park but worth the walk if you like a struggle.

 Near the end of the green trail past the Murder Rock.

 GPS data: (43.4839254,-70.4445606)

content.description: A short but fun problem with great holds. Start with right hand sidepull and left hand on the edge with good feet, then climb to the top by bumping the right hand followed by swinging the left to the crimp above. Nice easy move to the nice edge on top. Either climb for a short V0 or continue by traversing to a far decent hold for a little extra challenge. A high right foot makes it easy to get a right hand over, followed by a high left foot to match with the left hand. Bump the right hand over around the corner to the top without swinging and look for a nice right foot along the corner. Mantle and top out.
content.protection: A pad is recommended to avoid the sticks in the landing
content.location: Nearby the Peace Stem on the opposite side of the trail. Visible off the side of the trail in a wet and rocky area. Avoid if its rained recently.

content.description:
The climb leads directly up the ladder of drilled monos.

 A fall leads directly to the hospital.
content.protection: Just don't fall.
content.location:
On the south side of the Pinnacle. 

 GPS data: (43.4819320,-70.4529740)

content.description:
Start on the obvious shelf and work your way up and right to a jug. See photo.

 ** make sure you take a good look at holds on this wall before climbing as there are many that might blow off on you.
content.protection: Pad might be nice. Not necessary
content.location: Behind the "Iron spike" and down the hill. Same location as Rock Slug and Spinal Flake

climbs.name: Ain't Nothin' but a Tree Thang

content.description: Start out on good holds with slabby feet. Work up easy moves into the obvious hand crack. Continue over two small 'trees', top out up and left. Basic crack climbing skills make this a fairly easy but fun route. Can be done as a top rope or high-ball boulder.To the right of Sea Legs, and Slabcrack

Definitely not the first to do this, but worthy of a post on Mountain Project. Start on the left low rail/jug, traverse right on the rail just above the peace symbol, and top out right of it. Gets the PG13 for the landing having a downhill drop zone, should definitely have a spotter!
content.protection: Pad and spotter
content.location: Near many of the Peace Stem boulders, right on the face, can’t miss it!

content.description:
This climb is harder than it looks. Slippery slab climbing with some potential to stem the left facing rock. 

 Thins out up top. For extra challenge only use the slab... just don't fall. The landing zone isn't great.

 V1 if  using both rock faces V2+ if only using slab
content.protection:
A pad, friend and a prayer.  

  The fall here isn't great...so don't fall.
content.location:
Large boulder with large peace-sign spraypainted on it. This climb is the left most crack in the area. A tree marks the base of the route.

 The Peace Stem area is on the south side of the Blue Trail. Look at main page Climbing Map for general location.

 GPS Data: (43.484168,-70.451607)​​​​

content.description:
Clifford Park is an amazing outdoor escape but not just for the climbing. If you visit Clifford Park it isn't just to climb. There are designated walking / trail-running loops that total 15 miles with many more unofficial trails that are frequented by mountain bikers and wildlife. Its even possible to link trails to Smith Preserve and down to Cape Porpoise. Gorham Bike and Ski runs weekly MTB rides and can help you find new trails (facebook.com/gbssaco/)

 ***Clifford Park has a bad reputation for trash, broken glass, and the occasional squatter. Just be safe, pick up some trash if you can, and have a great time!

 ROCK HISTORY The rocks follow two main granite veins which cross the park East to West. These granite rocks were part of a multitude of quarries dating back to the 1800s. The largest collection of mines belonged to the Andrews Quarries which were most active in 1886. Biddeford granite was used in construction of the military forts near Portland, the Lincoln Monument in Illinois, and multiple bridge foundations in NYC. There is frequent quarry / mining evidence throughout the park and it makes for some fun climbing around blocky slabs of forgotten quarries. Happy exploring!

 THE CLIMBING The most appealing climbs with the least amount of lichen have been posted here, but if you are eager to get scrubbing or climb harder routes there are more climbs out there to find.

 PEAK SEASON The climbing season here is very similar to Pawtuckaway or any NE climbing. Early spring and late fall are prime to avoid the bugs.
